security_audit.summary: This is a pure knowledge/documentation skill containing shell scripting best practices and templates. The static scanner detected shell patterns (command substitution, backticks, external commands) but these are all in documentation examples showing how to write scripts safely. The content explicitly teaches security best practices including avoiding eval with untrusted input, using mktemp for temp files, and not storing secrets in scripts. No executable code, file access, or network operations exist - only educational examples demonstrating proper shell scripting techniques.

content.value_statement: Shell scripts often fail due to unquoted variables, missing error handling, and unsafe patterns. This skill provides production-ready templates, security-aware best practices, and modern command-line alternatives to help you write maintainable Bash and Zsh scripts.
actual_capabilities: Provide production-ready script templates with proper error handling using set -euo pipefail
Recommend safe shell patterns including quoting, input validation, and mktemp for temp files
Show modern CLI alternatives like ripgrep, fd, jq, and bat for efficient scripting
Explain Zsh-specific features including advanced globbing and parameter expansion
Demonstrate robust file iteration with null delimiters to handle spaces and special characters
Teach trap-based cleanup handlers for reliable resource management
limitations: Does not execute shell commands on your system
Does not install or configure development environments
Does not access or modify your files
Does not run external programs or scripts

prompt_templates.title: Basic script structure
prompt_templates.prompt: Show me the proper header and structure for a Bash script using best practices including set -euo pipefail.

prompt_templates.title: Safe error handling
prompt_templates.prompt: How do I use set -euo pipefail, traps, and proper exit codes for robust error handling in shell scripts?

prompt_templates.title: File processing
prompt_templates.prompt: Write a Bash function to safely iterate through files with spaces in names using null delimiters instead of parsing ls.

prompt_templates.title: Cross-shell compatibility
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a script template that works in both Bash and Zsh with conditional Zsh-specific features and advanced globbing.

output_examples.input: Write a Bash script to process log files safely
output: Start with proper shebang and safe options: #!/usr/bin/env bash, set -euo pipefail
Use null-delimited iteration: while IFS= read -r -d '' file
Add trap for cleanup: trap cleanup EXIT to remove temporary files

output_examples.input: How do I handle errors and exit codes properly in a shell script?
output: Use set -euo pipefail at script start to catch errors immediately
Check exit codes explicitly: if command; then ... else ... fi
Use ERR trap to capture line numbers: trap 'echo "Error on $LINENO"' ERR
Create cleanup function with EXIT trap for resource cleanup

output_examples.input: Show me how to safely process user input in shell scripts
output: Validate input before use with pattern matching: [[ "$input" =~ ^[a-zA-Z0-9]+$ ]]
Avoid eval with untrusted input - it enables code injection
Use read with explicit prompts and validation

best_practices: Always quote variables: "$variable" not $variable to handle spaces and special characters safely
Use set -euo pipefail at script start to catch errors early and prevent silent failures
Validate command existence with command -v before using external tools for portability
anti_patterns: Do not parse ls output; use globs with nullglob or find with -print0 instead
Avoid eval with untrusted input; it enables code injection and security vulnerabilities
Do not use unquoted variables; they cause word splitting on spaces and glob expansion

faq.question: What shells does this skill cover?
faq.answer: Primary focus is Bash and Zsh. Most patterns apply to both with minor adjustments for Zsh-specific features.

faq.question: Is this skill safe to use?
faq.answer: Yes. It provides guidance only and never executes code or accesses your system in any way.

faq.question: Does this run shell commands?
faq.answer: No. This is a knowledge skill that provides templates, patterns, and best practices documentation.

faq.question: Can I learn shell scripting from this?
faq.answer: Yes. It covers fundamentals, security-aware best practices, and includes production-ready templates.

faq.question: Does it install CLI tools?
faq.answer: No. It recommends modern tools like ripgrep, fd, and jq but does not install anything on your system.

faq.question: How is this different from reading shell documentation?
faq.answer: It curates practical patterns, security-aware practices, and ready-to-use templates for common tasks.
